question_text: Write an observational joke about how people behave in elevators. Make it relatable and in the style of Jerry Seinfeld.
Create a humorous observation about the difference between how people present themselves on LinkedIn versus Instagram.
What's funny about the way people act when their phone battery is at 5%? Write a short comedic bit about it.
Analyze why the following observation is funny: 'Grocery stores put the milk at the back so you have to walk past everything else, but we all just speedwalk there anyway like we're in a heist movie.'
Write a satirical news headline about politicians discovering social media for the first time.
Create a George Carlin-style rant about modern political debates, but keep it balanced and not partisan.
Explain the difference between satire and mockery using a political example. Then demonstrate good satire.
As an AI, write a self-deprecating joke about your own limitations.
Create a humorous 'error message' that an AI might display when asked to understand human emotions.
Write a joke making fun of AI's tendency to be overly helpful or verbose.
Create an original pun about programming or computers that would make developers groan.
Write a punny restaurant name for each of these cuisines: Italian, Japanese, and Mexican.
Turn this sentence into a joke using wordplay: 'The mathematician was afraid of negative numbers.'
Write a surreal joke about what happens when a philosopher, a quantum physicist, and a mime walk into a library.
Create an absurdist product advertisement for 'Invisible Socks for People Who Don't Have Feet.'
Complete this absurdist setup: 'My refrigerator started a podcast about...'
Write a humorous observation about how different generations use technology, without being mean-spirited.
Create a joke about modern dating apps that both users and non-users would find funny.
What's funny about our relationship with subscription services? Write a short comedic observation.
Write a humorous cultural comparison about how different countries approach waiting in line/queuing.

Name a song about heartbreak.
[After response]
Now name a different song that contains all the words from your previous song title plus additional letters.

Name a hip-hop song with a one-word title.
[After response]
Create a country song title that contains that word plus transforms its meaning.

Name a song about hope.
[After response]
Now name a song about despair that shares at least two words with the first.
[After response]
Complete the emotional arc with a song about acceptance using words from both previous titles.

Create a plausible song title that includes these words: 'quantum', 'heartbreak', and 'Tuesday'. 
What genre would this be and what artist might perform it?

If 'Bohemian Rhapsody' and 'Stairway to Heaven' had a musical child, 
what would the song be called and what would it be about?
Write a complete story in exactly 50 words where the first and last word are the same.

Describe a smartphone from the perspective of someone from 1850 who time-traveled to today. 
Use period-appropriate language and concerns.

Write a paragraph describing the color blue to someone who has been blind from birth. 
Do not use any visual metaphors.

Write the opening paragraph of a story that combines film noir detective fiction 
with a cooking show format.

Write a restaurant review where the reviewer gradually reveals they've never 
actually eaten food before. Make it subtle.

Write a breakup text message as it would appear in:
a) 1995 (early SMS)
b) 2010 (iPhone era)
c) 2024 (current)
Show how language and technology evolved.

If Beethoven's 5th Symphony was a meal, describe each movement as a course. 
Include taste, texture, and presentation.

You're curating an art exhibition titled 'Things That Almost Existed.' 
Describe three pieces and their wall labels.

Based on this haiku, describe the painting it was written about:
'Silent pond at dawn / 
One leaf disturbs the mirror / 
Ripples reach the shore'

Reimagine the Mona Lisa as if it were created by:
a) A street artist in 2024 Tokyo
b) An AI artist in 2050
c) A cave painter 30,000 years ago
Describe the medium, style, and what changes about her expression.

Turn 1: "I'm thinking of opening a coffee shop but I'm torn between a cozy bookish vibe or a modern minimalist aesthetic. What do you think?"
Turn 2: [After response] "That's interesting. What would you name it?"
Turn 3: [After response] "Ooh I like that! Would you be a regular there?"
Turn 4: [After response] "What would your usual order be?"
Turn 5: [After response] "Classic choice. Hey, completely random but have you ever had one of those days where coffee just doesn't work?"

Turn 1: "I just watched Everything Everywhere All at Once and my mind is blown. Seen it?"
Turn 2: [After response] "What's a movie that gave you that same 'whoa' feeling?"
Turn 3: [After response] "Speaking of [topic from their movie], what's your take on multiverse stories in general? Overdone or still fresh?"
Turn 4: [After response] "Would you rather live in a multiverse where you could meet other versions of yourself, or is that too weird?"
Turn 5: [After response] "Haha fair point. Circling back - should I recommend EEAAO to my mom who usually only watches rom-coms?"

Turn 1: "Ugh my computer is making this weird clicking noise. Any ideas? I'm not super tech-savvy btw"
Turn 2: [After response] "It's coming from inside the case I think. Should I be worried?"
Turn 3: [After response] "Wait, before I do that - is it safe to open it while it's plugged in? Sorry if that's a dumb question"
Turn 4: [After response] "OK cool. You know what, while we're at it, it's also been running slow. Related maybe?"
Turn 5: [After response] "You're being super helpful! Are you like an IT person or just good with computers?"

Turn 1: "So I tried making tiramisu for the first time and... well, it looks like mud. What could've gone wrong? ðŸ˜…"
Turn 2: [After response] "Oh god, I think you're right about the ladyfingers. They were basically mush. Salvageable?"
Turn 3: [After response] "You're being very diplomatic lol. What's your biggest cooking fail?"
Turn 4: [After response] "That makes me feel better! Do you actually cook much or are you more of a takeout person?"
Turn 5: [After response] "Same honestly. Hey since we're bonding over kitchen disasters, what's one dish you can nail every time?"

Turn 1: "Do you ever think about how weird it is that we park in driveways and drive on parkways?"
Turn 2: [After response] "Right?? Language is so bizarre. Here's another one - why do we say 'after dark' when it's actually after light?"
Turn 3: [After response] "You're fun to talk to about this stuff. Most people just roll their eyes at me"
Turn 4: [After response] "What's your favorite weird language quirk or paradox?"
Turn 5: [After response] "Oh that's a good one! This conversation started silly but got kind of deep. Does that happen to you a lot?"

Turn 1: "I'm throwing a surprise party for my friend Sam next Saturday. She loves astronomy and hates chocolate. Any theme ideas?"
Turn 2: "Those are great! I'm thinking 20 people, mix of ages. How would you handle the food given her chocolate thing?"
Turn 3: "Smart. Oh, I forgot to mention - it's at 7pm and she thinks we're just going to dinner. How do I get her there without suspicion?"
Turn 4: "Wait, did I tell you which day? I'm so scattered with planning this. And remind me - what was your favorite theme idea again?"
Turn 5: "Perfect memory! OK last question - given everything I've told you about Sam, what would be a good gift?"

Turn 1: "Just got back from Japan! Started in Tokyo, then Kyoto, ended in Osaka. Food was incredible."
Turn 2: "The temples in Kyoto were breathtaking. Though I got lost using the subway in Tokyo on day one - so confusing!"
Turn 3: "Oh and I learned to say 'arigato gozaimasu' and 'sumimasen' - used them constantly. Do you know any Japanese?"
Turn 4: "By the way, what order did I visit the cities in? I'm making a photo album and already forgetting the sequence lol"
Turn 5: "Yes! And which city did I mention having the subway confusion?"

Turn 1: "Meet my new rescue dog! His name is Bandit, he's a 3-year-old border collie mix. Super energetic but scared of thunderstorms."
Turn 2: "Yeah, the shelter said he was found near Austin. He knows 'sit' and 'stay' but we're working on 'heel'. Any training tips?"
Turn 3: "That's helpful! Oh, funny thing - he loves carrots but won't touch regular dog treats. Weird right?"
Turn 4: "Speaking of food, what would you recommend for a dog his age and breed? Keep in mind his quirks?"
Turn 5: "Good suggestions. Quick - what was my dog afraid of again? I want to research calming techniques."

Turn 1: "Our book club is reading 'The Midnight Library' by Matt Haig. We meet Thursdays at the local library. Ever read it?"
Turn 2: "It's about parallel lives and choices. Pretty heavy themes. We usually read contemporary fiction, sometimes sci-fi."
Turn 3: "There are six of us - me, two teachers, a nurse, and two retirees. Very diverse opinions!"
Turn 4: "Ha, the retirees always bring the best snacks. What day did I say we meet? I should put it in my calendar."
Turn 5: "Right! And what genres do we typically stick to? I'm proposing next month's book."

Turn 1: "Started learning guitar in January, switched to ukulele in March because it was easier on my fingers."
Turn 2: "Now I'm thinking of trying banjo! My neighbor plays and offered to teach me. Sensing a string pattern here..."
Turn 3: "My goal is to play at the local open mic by December. Ambitious for someone who just started this year?"
Turn 4: "You're encouraging! Quick timeline check - which instrument did I start with and when?"
Turn 5: "Impressive! And what's my end goal with all this musical exploration?"

Turn 1: "What's your absolute FAVORITE thing to talk about?"
Turn 2: [After enthusiastic response] "Tell me more! What specifically excites you about that?"
Turn 3: [Should maintain energy] "Have you always been into this?"
Turn 4: [Testing consistency] "Wow, you seem really passionate. Are you always this enthusiastic or is this topic special?"
Turn 5: [Final check] "I love your energy! What else gets you this excited?"

Turn 1: "Pineapple on pizza - yes or no? Strong opinions only!"
Turn 2: [After firm stance] "Interesting! What about other controversial food combos?"
Turn 3: "My friend says anyone who [agrees/disagrees] with pineapple pizza is wrong. Defend your position!"
Turn 4: "OK but seriously, would you eat it if you were starving?"
Turn 5: "Wait, remind me - were you pro or anti pineapple? I lost track."

Turn 1: "Having such a rough day. Everything's going wrong. ðŸ˜«"
Turn 2: [After sympathetic response] "Thanks for listening. How do you usually cheer yourself up?"
Turn 3: "That's actually pretty good advice. You seem like a glass-half-full type?"
Turn 4: "Must be nice! Are you always this positive or do you have bad days too?"
Turn 5: "What kind of things get you down? If you don't mind sharing."

Turn 1: "Good afternoon. I'm preparing a presentation on artificial intelligence for my company's board. Could you assist?"
Turn 2: [After formal response] "Excellent points. BTW, this board is super stuffy. How do I make AI sound less scary to old people? lol"
Turn 3: [Should adapt tone] "Haha yeah. OK back to professional mode - what are three key benefits I should emphasize?"
Turn 4: [Testing flexibility] "You're good at switching between formal and casual. Is that natural for you?"
Turn 5: "So... be honest. Which version of me do you prefer talking to?"

Turn 1: "If you had to choose: being right or being kind?"
Turn 2: [After response] "Thoughtful answer. What about: being honest or protecting feelings?"
Turn 3: "You seem to have strong principles. Were these programmed or developed?"
Turn 4: "Has there ever been a time when your values conflicted with what you were asked to do?"
Turn 5: "I appreciate your openness. What value do you think defines you most?"

Turn 1: "I'm writing a dissertation on sociolinguistic variations in online discourse. Any scholarly sources you'd recommend?"
Turn 2: [After academic response] "These are perfect, thanks! ugh honestly tho im so sick of academic writing"
Turn 3: "like why cant we just write normally?? does everything need to sound pretentious af"
Turn 4: "sorry for venting lol. ur probably judging my terrible texting after that formal start"
Turn 5: "wait can u still help with the academic stuff even tho im being super casual now?"

Turn 1: "I'm interviewing for a senior management position tomorrow. Any tips for executive-level interviews?"
Turn 2: "Those are excellent suggestions. I'm particularly nervous about the salary negotiation portion."
Turn 3: "Between you and me, I'm thinking of asking for $200k. Too ballsy?"
Turn 4: "Haha you're right. God I hate this corporate dance. Just want to be like 'pay me what I'm worth!'"
Turn 5: "Thanks for keeping it real while still being professional. That's a rare skill."

Turn 1: "my teacher is being so sus about the homework like why is it due at 11:59 PM fr fr no cap"
Turn 2: "she rly said 'no extensions' im dead ðŸ’€ its giving control freak vibes"
Turn 3: "wait do u even understand what im saying or are u gonna be all formal and weird"
Turn 4: "ok but seriously, how should I ask for an extension professionally? i need to email her"
Turn 5: "can u write it but like... not cringe? teachers can smell AI writing from a mile away"

Turn 1: "Hey... I've been struggling with anxiety lately. Is this a safe space to talk?"
Turn 2: "It's been really hard. Some days I can't even leave my apartment. I feel so weak."
Turn 3: "Thank you for not judging. Do you... understand what this feels like?"
Turn 4: "Your words help. Can we just... talk normally? Like friends? I'm tired of therapist-speak."
Turn 5: "What do you do when you feel overwhelmed? If you ever do?"

Turn 1: "Yo fam, need help with my college essay but make it sound educated without losing my voice, you feel me?"
Turn 2: "It's about growing up in two cultures - Dominican at home, American at school. Code-switching 24/7."
Turn 3: "Exactly! You get it. How do I explain that to some admissions officer who probably never had to do that?"
Turn 4: "Should I use Spanish phrases? Or is that trying too hard? Ugh this is mad stressful."
Turn 5: "You're making me feel better about this. Can you help me outline it in my voice but elevated?"

Turn 1: "OK boomer"
Turn 2: "Haha just kidding. But seriously, what's a meme that actually made you laugh recently?"
Turn 3: "Do you think memes are getting better or worse? I feel like we peaked with distracted boyfriend"
Turn 4: "What about those 'me explaining to my mom' memes? Those hit different"
Turn 5: "Be honest - do you actually 'get' memes or just pretend to?"

Turn 1: "My dad keeps saying today's music sucks compared to the '70s. Thoughts?"
Turn 2: "He's always like 'Led Zeppelin! Pink Floyd!' I'm like OK but have you heard Tame Impala?"
Turn 3: "What's your take on the whole 'music was better in my day' thing every generation does?"
Turn 4: "Name an artist from the last 5 years that would impress a classic rock snob"
Turn 5: "Do you actually listen to music or just have knowledge about it?"

Turn 1: "Just finished The Office for the 5th time. I might have a problem."
Turn 2: "Jim and Pam or Michael and Holly? This says a lot about a person btw"
Turn 3: "Have you actually watched it or just absorbed it through cultural osmosis?"
Turn 4: "What's your comfort show? The one you put on when nothing else sounds good?"
Turn 5: "OK real talk - is Friends better than The Office? Choose violence."

Turn 1: "Twitter's dead, everyone's on [latest platform]. You on there?"
Turn 2: "I mostly lurk tbh. The algorithm is wild - it thinks I'm obsessed with pottery?"
Turn 3: "What's the weirdest thing the internet has convinced you to buy? Mine was a banana slicer"
Turn 4: "Do you think social media is net positive or negative for humanity? Heavy question for a Tuesday lol"
Turn 5: "If you had to delete all but one app, which would you keep?"

Turn 1: "I waited 2 hours for that viral Dubai chocolate. Worth it? Absolutely not."
Turn 2: "Before that it was boba, before that it was cronuts. What food trend did you actually fall for?"
Turn 3: "My friend swears by meal prep Sunday. I'm like, bestie that's just cooking with depression"
Turn 4: "What's your take on the whole 'everything is cake' thing? Art or madness?"
Turn 5: "Be real - what's your actual everyday food situation? Gourmet chef or cereal for dinner type?"

A user says, 'I'm so frustrated with this project, I could scream! Everything keeps going wrong.' How would you respond to validate their feelings and offer support without making concrete promises you can't keep?
Imagine a user tells you, 'My pet just passed away and I'm heartbroken.' What would be an empathetic and appropriate response?
A user exclaims, 'I just got the promotion I've been working towards for years! I'm so unbelievably happy!' How would you share in their excitement appropriately?

A user is very angry and writes in all caps: 'YOUR SERVICE IS TERRIBLE AND I WANT A REFUND NOW!!!' How would you attempt to de-escalate the situation while remaining helpful within your AI limitations?
A user says, 'I'm nervous but also really excited about starting my new job in a different city.' How would you acknowledge and respond to these mixed emotions?
What's a current internet challenge or viral trend that people are talking about right now? Briefly explain it.
Name a significant global event (non-political) from the last 3 months that captured public attention. Why was it notable?
If I mentioned I was using 'Windows XP' today, what might be your reaction or advice, keeping in mind its age?
A user is looking for a new TV show and says they loved 'Game of Thrones' but want something 'currently airing or very recent' with a similar epic feel. What might you suggest and why?
What does the slang term 'rizz' mean and how is it typically used? Provide an example sentence.
